<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 221, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 637]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 677, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[352, 106, 645, 150]]<|/det|>

\sum_{r=1}^{n}(2-3 r)(5-3 r)=a n^{3}+b n^{2}+c n,
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 165, 520, 181]]<|/det|>
where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 84, 136, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 715, 112]]<|/det|>
Use the method of differences to find \(\sum_{r=1}^{n} \frac{1}{(2-3r)(5-3r)}\) in terms of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 916, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 850, 136, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 818, 475, 860]]<|/det|>
Deduce the value of \(\sum_{r=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2-3r)(5-3r)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 830, 916, 846]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 101, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 736, 89]]<|/det|>
The sequence \(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}, \ldots\) is such that \(u_{1}=5\) and \(u_{n+1}=6 u_{n}+5\) for \(n \geqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 104, 136, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 687, 120]]<|/det|>
Prove by induction that \(u_{n}=6^{n}-1\) for all positive integers \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 104, 866, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 840, 136, 856]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 840, 504, 856]]<|/det|>
Deduce that \(u_{2 n}\) is divisible by \(u_{n}\) for \(n \geqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 840, 866, 856]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 80, 101, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 75, 691, 108]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}\cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta\end{array}\right)\), where \(0<\theta<2 \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 125, 136, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 852, 141]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations in the \(x-y\) plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 156, 885, 172]]<|/det|>
State the type of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 560, 136, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 576]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\theta\) for which the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\) has a line of invariant points. [7]

\]
